introduction.paragraph1: So after I had grasped the basic idea – Spain could really become my new home – and the advantages I saw in it outweighed my initial fears, it was time to make a real plan. The dream alone is not enough. I wanted to understand: Is this whole thing even feasible? What requirements do I have to meet? And what could a realistic timeline look like?
introduction.paragraph2: Fortunately, the internet is full of information – and of course, I'm not the first German to consider emigrating to Spain. A real constant companion of my research became Idealista. For those who don't know: Idealista is not only the largest real estate platform in Spain (comparable to Immoscout24 in Germany), but also a real treasure trove of information.

step1.title: The Dream of Spain
step1.description: Where did the idea come from? Why Spain? First thoughts, wishes, fears.

intro.title: The Beginning of a Dream
intro.description: Every journey begins with a single thought. For me, it was the idea of living in Spain - a country that had always fascinated me with its culture, climate, and way of life.

dream.title: The Dream
dream.description: The dream of Spain started with simple thoughts during vacations - watching the sunset, feeling the warm breeze, and wondering what it would be like to call this place home.
dream.point3: Beautiful landscapes from beaches to mountains
dream.point4: Slower, more relaxed pace of life

whySpain.title: Why Spain?
whySpain.description: Spain offered everything I was looking for in a new home - from practical benefits to emotional connections that made the decision feel right.
whySpain.point2: Affordable cost of living compared to other European countries
whySpain.point4: Rich history and diverse regions to explore

fears.title: Fears and Doubts
fears.description: Despite the excitement, there were real concerns that needed to be addressed before taking such a life-changing step.
fears.point3: Navigating bureaucracy in a foreign country

conclusion.title: The Decision
conclusion.description: After weighing all the pros and cons, the dream of Spain felt worth pursuing. The fears were real, but the potential rewards seemed even greater.

hero.title: Where Did the Idea Come From?
hero.subtitle: If you've landed here, you probably know this impulse: You're sitting on vacation in Spain, looking at the sea, and thinking: 'Why don't I just stay here?'
hero.imagePlaceholder: Sunset at the beach / typical Spain feeling

beginning.title: The Beginning
beginning.paragraph1: That's exactly how it started for me. Spain has always appealed to me – many warm days a year, an open and warm culture, endless sandy beaches, but also mountainous landscapes for hiking. Everything I longed for while sitting in a cold office in Germany or looking out the window on gray weekends.
beginning.paragraph2: The contrast between my current life and the potential future became clear, and I began to think about what a different life could look like.
beginning.imagePlaceholder: Sunset at the beach / typical Spain feeling

turningPoint.title: A Personal Turning Point
turningPoint.paragraph1: In April 2022, I was diagnosed with celiac disease. Suddenly I couldn't eat normal bread anymore, couldn't have conventional oatmeal for breakfast, and even eating out became a challenge. Especially in the countryside in Germany, it was almost impossible to find something suitable spontaneously.
turningPoint.paragraph2: Supermarkets offered hardly any selection, restaurants had no gluten-free options – my everyday life felt severely restricted.
turningPoint.question: This situation led to the question: Can't this be done better somewhere else?
turningPoint.answer: And that's exactly what brought me back to Spain.
turningPoint.imagePlaceholder: A set table with gluten-free bread / food symbol image

research.title: First Research
research.paragraph1: To my surprise, I quickly came across positive reports: Spanish supermarkets had a significantly larger selection of gluten-free products – from tortillas to bread to cookies and cakes. Restaurants were also often set up to safely serve people with celiac disease.
research.paragraph2: And at this point my decision was firm: I wanted to find a way to live in Spain. Not just because of sun and prices – but because I saw the chance to live more simply and carefree there.

fears.title: First Ideas – and Fears
fears.subtitle: At first I thought it was simple: Find a property, move there, done. But I quickly realized it was about much more. Such a step is not a move 'to the next town' – it's a fresh start in a foreign country.

fear1.title: Can I do this alone?
fear1.description: The biggest question was whether I could handle all the bureaucracy, language barriers, and cultural differences on my own.

fear2.title: Leaving loved ones behind
fear2.description: How would it feel to leave family and friends behind? Would I be able to maintain these important relationships from afar?

fear3.title: Language barriers
fear3.description: How would I get by without language skills? Would I be able to communicate effectively in everyday situations?

fears.conclusion: Many nights I lay awake and went through these questions in my head.

firstStep.title: The Most Important First Step
firstStep.description: Alongside all the bureaucratic things I still had to clarify, there was one task I could start immediately – and which turned out to be absolutely crucial in hindsight: Learning Spanish.

option1.title: Traditional Learning
option1.description: Using textbooks and language courses to build a solid foundation in Spanish grammar and vocabulary.

option2.title: Digital Learning
option2.description: Using language apps and online resources for flexible, mobile learning that fits into any schedule.

step2.title: First Research & Feasibility
step2.description: First info gathering: residence rights, taxes, cost of living. Notes & rough plan: "What would I need to do to actually emigrate?"

preview.point1: First info gathering: residence rights, taxes, cost of living
preview.point2: Notes & rough plan: "What would I need to do to actually emigrate?"

intro.title: The Most Important Thing First
intro.question: Can I as a German really live in Spain so easily?
intro.answer: The short answer: Yes. As an EU citizen, I have the right to settle, live and work in any EU member state – without any visa or residence permit. This right is called freedom of movement and is regulated in EU regulations.
intro.note: Sounds easy at first. But in practice there are naturally details:

registration.title: Registration Requirement from 3 Months
registration.point1: Anyone staying longer than 3 months must register with the immigration office (Extranjería)
registration.point2: You receive the so-called "Certificado de registro como residente comunitario"
registration.point3: For this you need income, employment contract or proof of sufficient financial means

taxRule.title: The 183-Day Rule
taxRule.conclusion: From 183 days onwards, tax residency in Spain applies.

work.title: Work
work.intro: Of course, work was a central topic for me. After all, like most people, I depend on my income. My research quickly showed me: In principle, there are two options for me.

remote.title: Option 1: Remote Work from Germany
remote.point2: Security because you stay with the German employer
remote.point3: Social security system remains the same
remote.point4: Flexibility: you can travel without immediately changing all systems in Spain
remote.warning: 183-day rule → as soon as I stay too long in Spain, it becomes tax complicated

spain.title: Option 2: Working directly in Spain
spain.disadvantage: Salaries in Spain are on average significantly lower than German ones. 2025: Spain ~28,000€ vs. Germany ~46,000€

decision.title: Remote Work as a Transition Solution
decision.description: As a transition, I'm starting with remote work. This helped me immensely – I could arrange everything on site (bank account, Gestoría, apartment, etc.) without having to take vacation each time. And yes, it saved me a lot of money for flights.
decision.reminder: Anyone working remotely from Spain should keep an eye on the 183-day rule

taxes.title: Taxes & Salary Calculation
taxes.intro: Taxes were the next big topic – after all, you don't want to fall into a trap. Here I show you a detailed salary calculation for €2,500 gross comparing Germany vs. Spain.

summary.title: Summary
summary.conclusion: With €2,500 gross, about 15% more net remains in Spain than in Germany. Deductions are significantly higher in Germany (36.8% vs. 27.1% of gross).
summary.importantNote: In Spain, it is significantly more difficult to achieve a salary of €2,500 gross. The average salary is around €1,800 gross, while in Germany it's around €3,200.
summary.disclaimer: This calculation is an example. Actual deductions depend on many factors. Consultation with a tax advisor is recommended.

livingCosts.title: Cost of Living
livingCosts.intro: Everyone who goes on vacation in Spain says at first: "Wow, everything here is so cheap!" But that's only half the truth. Yes, a tapa for €2.50 and a café con leche for €1.20 seem ridiculously cheap to us Germans. But the feeling arises mainly because we have German salaries in mind.

intro.title: An Unexpected Advantage
intro.description: As someone with celiac disease, this was a real game-changer for me. I hadn't expected Spain to be so much better equipped in this area than Germany.

positiveSurprise.title: Positive Surprise in Spain
positiveSurprise.description1: In Spain, I was honestly positively surprised. Even during my first stays, I noticed that awareness of gluten-free nutrition ("sin gluten") is much more pronounced here. Almost every larger supermarket has entire shelves with gluten-free products.
positiveSurprise.description2: Even when eating out, it often looks more relaxed in Spain. Many restaurants and cafés clearly mark their menus with "sin gluten" symbols, and there are chains like 100 Montaditos or VIPS that explicitly offer gluten-free options.

supermarkets.title: Supermarket chains with large gluten-free selection:
supermarkets.mercadona: Mercadona – probably the best first point of contact
supermarkets.carrefour: Carrefour – wide selection of brand products
supermarkets.alcampo: Alcampo – large hypermarkets with good coverage
supermarkets.lidl: Lidl Spain – some gluten-free own-brand products

conclusion.title: My Conclusion
conclusion.description: Spain is a really good country for people with celiac disease. The combination of large product selection in supermarkets, diverse natural cuisine, and growing awareness in gastronomy makes everyday life here much easier for me.

step3.title: First Steps: Learning Spanish
step3.description: Why learning Spanish is so important and how I approached it - from Duolingo to books and flashcards.

preview.point1: Why learning Spanish is so important
preview.point2: My experiences with Duolingo and books
preview.point3: My flashcard system and online learning

hero.title: Without Spanish it doesn't work
hero.subtitle: Through the research in the previous step, I learned a lot – for example, that it can be interesting from a tax perspective to work in Spain, or that there is a much greater variety of gluten-free alternatives there than I would have thought. But one insight was even more important: Without Spanish it doesn't work.

introduction.title: Why learning Spanish is so important
introduction.paragraph1: Of course, you can get by with English or even German in Spain in some places. In classic tourist regions like the Costa Blanca or Mallorca, there are often even German supermarkets or restaurants, and in big cities like Madrid or Barcelona, many speak at least a little English.
introduction.paragraph2: But as soon as you get to know the "real Spain" – smaller cities, offices, doctor visits, neighborhood conversations – you quickly realize that you're lost without Spanish. I didn't want to be one of those "emigrants" who have been living in Spain for years but still can barely put together a sentence in Spanish. So it was clear to me: I have to learn Spanish.

duolingo.title: My start with Duolingo
duolingo.paragraph1: First, I turned to Duolingo back then. I liked the idea of "learning while playing": One lesson during coffee break, another one just before falling asleep – that was perfect to integrate into my everyday life. I even took the premium version because I hoped to achieve results faster with it.
duolingo.paragraph2: And yes, at the beginning it worked: I could practice as much as I wanted and saw quick progress. But over time, I noticed that something was missing. The lessons are entertaining, but they remain very superficial. It's more like rote memorization than real understanding.
duolingo.paragraph3: I had no overview of grammar, no clear structure for verb conjugations, and pronouns were only treated in passing. After 2-3 months, I lost interest – and switched to the classic method: books, notes, flashcards.

books.title: My book recommendations
books.intro: After my experience with Duolingo, I found that traditional learning with books was easiest for me. The structured explanations of grammar helped me internalize the rules better and build a solid foundation. Especially the visual elements in books – whether through tables, diagrams, or colored markings – helped me remember the rules more easily. Based on my learning experience, I can therefore recommend the following books:

book1.title: Spanish – Grammar Concise & Clear
book1.author: by Daniela Wakonigg
book1.description: A clearly structured beginner's book that starts from zero and teaches the basics step by step. Each chapter first covers the theory (e.g., tenses, pronouns, sentence structure) and then offers exercises and vocabulary lists. Additionally, there is online material for listening comprehension tasks.
book1.review: Super helpful for the initial start in Spanish. The book brings you closer to your first own sentences step by step. I particularly liked the combination of theory, exercises, and vocabulary – it strongly reminds me of school lessons, just more compact. With the online listening comprehension tasks, I could also directly train speaking and understanding. All in all, exactly what you need to be able to communicate a little in everyday life.

book2.title: Spanish Stories for Beginners: 100 Simple Stories for Learning Spanish – with Vocabulary and Exercises
book2.author: by Christian Stahl
book2.description: This book consists of short, clearly written stories that are specifically designed for beginners. Each story is simple enough to be understood without much effort, and yet you constantly learn new words and sentence structures.
book2.review: Every now and then I wanted to check how my Spanish skills were doing – and for that, the book is great. You quickly notice that you're having small successes, and through the audio files you can additionally train your listening comprehension.

book3.title: Spanish – 5-Minute Stories A1/A2 with Audio
book3.author: PONS
book3.description: This book offers short, simple stories that are tailored to beginner level (A1-A2). Each story can be read in just a few minutes and is perfect for small learning units in between.
book3.review: For me, it was a great way to make small learning progress even in everyday life. The marked vocabulary made reading easy, the mind maps helped me remember words faster, and with the audio I could additionally train my listening comprehension. This made it feel like a "mini language course" in the form of stories – light, motivating, and effective.

flashcards.title: My flashcard system
flashcards.intro: For vocabulary learning, I built myself a 6-stage box using the Leitner system. Writing the vocabulary words on flashcards helped me tremendously in memorizing them better. Through the physical act of writing them down, the words become much more deeply ingrained than through mere reading. Additionally, the system helped me stay on track – I always had a clear structure and knew exactly which vocabulary I had to repeat on which day. This helped me stay continuously engaged and track my learning progress. In short:
flashcards.systemTitle: The flashcard box system works like this:
flashcards.systemDescription: You have a box with 6 compartments. New vocabulary always starts in the first compartment. When you know a vocabulary word during testing, it moves one compartment further back. If you don't know it, it goes back to the very front in the first compartment. The further back the vocabulary is, the less often it gets tested. This way you repeat difficult vocabulary often and easy vocabulary only rarely – until they finally land in the last compartment and are considered "almost learned".

stage2.label: Stage 2
stage2.description: First successes come up less often

stage6.label: Stage 6
stage6.description: Rare control - the word is firmly established!

flashcards.step1: New vocabulary starts in compartment 1 and is repeated daily.
flashcards.step2: Every time you get them right, they move one level back – and come up less often.
flashcards.step3: Incorrect vocabulary goes back to the very front.
flashcards.step4: After a few weeks, the words land in compartment 6 – and are considered "learned".
flashcards.conclusion: The system sounds simple, but it's incredibly effective because you don't waste your time with vocabulary you already know anyway.

lingolia.title: Online learning with Lingolia
lingolia.paragraph1: After my books, I wanted something interactive as well. Like back in school during English lessons, just for Spanish. After a longer search, I came across Lingolia.
lingolia.paragraph2: There you'll find comprehensive theory texts, many exercises (some free, others behind a small paywall), and no annoying subscriptions. For me, the perfect complement to consolidate grammar and theory.

speaking.title: What helps most: Speaking
speaking.paragraph1: I learned a lot of theory and vocabulary before I dared to use a Spanish sentence in the "real world" for the first time. It takes courage to really start speaking – especially with native speakers. You're afraid of making mistakes, forgetting words, or simply not being understood.
speaking.paragraph2: But that's exactly what helped me most: simply speaking.
speaking.paragraph3: It works best with someone you're comfortable with and talk to a lot. I was very lucky to meet Emely during my first planning trip to Spain. With her, I could speak and write a lot from the beginning – first with many mistakes, then getting better and better. She took away my fear, and to this day she accompanies me not only in my Spanish adventure but also in my life – now as my girlfriend.
speaking.paragraph4: Looking back, that was the crucial step: Theory and vocabulary are the foundation, but you really learn when you start speaking. Every conversation, no matter how bumpy, moves you forward – and the success experience of being understood is enormously motivating.

currentStatus.title: My current status
currentStatus.paragraph1: Realistically speaking: I'm still learning Spanish. Even now, mid/late 2025, I practice daily – just in everyday life now. While shopping, in conversation with my girlfriend, with neighbors, or simply through Spanish TV.
currentStatus.paragraph2: You don't learn a language in a few weeks, but piece by piece. But Spanish is relatively easy, and you quickly have success experiences.
currentStatus.tip: My tip for anyone thinking about moving to Spain: Find the way that's fun for you. Whether app, books, flashcards, or series with subtitles – the important thing is just that you stick with it. Because with every vocabulary word and every sentence, you feel a bit more at home in Spain.

regionDecision.title: From Theory to Practice
regionDecision.subtitle: How I selected the Murcia region as my new home after intensive research and test trips.

introduction.title: From Theory to Practice
introduction.paragraph1: After intensive research and countless hours of planning, it was finally time to put theory into practice. I had gathered all the information, analyzed the different regions, and now I needed to experience Spain firsthand to make my final decision.
introduction.paragraph2: The choice of region would determine not only where I would live, but also my quality of life, costs, and integration opportunities. It was a decision that would shape my entire Spanish adventure.

population.title: Population Distribution
population.paragraph1: Spain's population is very unevenly distributed. While Madrid and Barcelona are bursting at the seams, many rural areas are experiencing significant depopulation. This creates interesting opportunities for those looking for a quieter life.
population.paragraph2: The coastal regions are particularly popular with expats, but this also means higher prices and more tourism. Inland regions often offer better value for money and more authentic Spanish life.

favorites.title: My Favorites List
favorites.intro: After extensive research, I had narrowed down my options to four regions that seemed most promising for my needs and preferences.

andalusia.title: Andalusia
andalusia.pros: For many, the classic "expat Spain". Lots of sun, lots of culture, sea and mountains right next to each other.
andalusia.cons: But for me, often already very touristy and not quite as attractive in terms of price.

valencia.title: Valencia
valencia.subtitle: A great mix of big city, sea and modern infrastructure.
valencia.pros: Modern metropolis with good infrastructure and access to the sea.
valencia.cons: But the metropolitan region is huge and very internationally oriented – I wanted it more Spanish and a bit quieter.

costaBlanca.title: Alicante & Costa Blanca
costaBlanca.subtitle: Many non-Spaniards, dreamy beaches, good infrastructure.
costaBlanca.pros: Dreamy beaches and good infrastructure for expats.
costaBlanca.cons: But that was exactly the problem: too many tourists, too many German bakeries. I wanted more authenticity.

murcia.title: Murcia
murcia.subtitle: A region that is often overlooked.
murcia.pros: Traditional, sunny, cheaper than many neighboring regions, while having good access to the sea.
murcia.cons: Even on paper, Murcia seemed to offer the perfect mix.

murcia.title: Murcia – City and Region
murcia.intro: Murcia is a region in southeastern Spain that is a bit underestimated. Many expats are drawn to Andalusia, Valencia or Catalonia – but Murcia often stays under the radar. That's exactly what made it exciting for me.
murcia.introExtended: What makes Murcia special is the combination of urban life and proximity to nature. Within minutes, you can go from the lively city center to the quiet mountains or the sea. This variety, combined with the warm Mediterranean climate and the welcoming atmosphere, makes Murcia a place where you immediately feel at home.

city.title: The City of Murcia
city.location: It's not directly on the sea, but in the fertile Segura Valley, which gives it a very special atmosphere.
city.atmosphere: Anyone visiting Murcia experiences narrow alleys with traditional bars, an imposing cathedral in the center, many festivals and a very traditional, Spanish flair.
city.modern: At the same time, there are modern districts, large shopping centers, universities and everything you need for everyday life.

region.title: The Murcia Region
region.subtitle: Offers even more
region.landscape: Wide plains with orange and lemon groves, small villages, mountains in the south.
region.coast: And not to forget the Mar Menor and the Mediterranean coast, which you can reach by car in under an hour.
region.climate: The climate is dry and sunny – almost desert-like – which personally suited me very well.

onSite.title: My Impression on Site
onSite.paragraph1: When I finally traveled to Murcia, I knew immediately: This could work. The city enchanted me right away. Everything felt very traditionally Spanish – exactly what I was looking for. Plus the big surprise: For my celiac disease, I found a really good selection of gluten-free food here.
onSite.paragraph2: I used the time not only to explore the city, but also to get to know the surrounding area. The mountains in the south gave me unforgettable sunsets, and when I felt like going to the sea, the coast was just 50 minutes away by car. In total, I spent over two months in Murcia – enough time to take away not just vacation feelings, but real everyday moments.

glutenFree.title: Gluten-Free Food
glutenFree.subtitle: A positive surprise
glutenFree.description: Both in supermarkets and restaurants, the selection was significantly larger than I would have expected. This took away much of my initial concern.

exploration.title: Explore the Surroundings
exploration.subtitle: Mountains and sea within reach
exploration.description: The mountains in the south gave me unforgettable sunsets, and the coast is only 50 minutes away by car.

cityCountry.title: Between City and Country
cityCountry.paragraph1: But despite all the positive impressions, I realized: The center of the city of Murcia was not quite ideal for me. Above all, the parking situation was chaotic – as someone who comes from the countryside, I found it difficult to constantly search for a parking space in overcrowded streets.
cityCountry.paragraph2: Also, the property prices in the center seemed less attractive compared to the surrounding area when weighing price and living quality against each other.

parking.title: Parking Problem
parking.subtitle: Chaotic parking situation
parking.description: As someone who comes from the countryside, I found it difficult to constantly search for a parking space in overcrowded streets.

prices.title: Property Prices
prices.subtitle: Center vs. surroundings
prices.description: The property prices in the center seemed less attractive compared to the surrounding area when weighing price and living quality against each other.

conclusion.title: The Decision is Made
conclusion.paragraph1: So it was clear to me: It will be the Murcia region – but not the city itself. The decision was made. On my next trips, it shouldn't just be about exploring anymore, but about the concrete property search.
conclusion.paragraph2: I had found a region that met all my criteria: warm, authentic, livable and with good infrastructure. Now it was about finding the perfect place within this region.

introduction.title: Introduction
introduction.paragraph1: Now it got serious! Vacation dreams and sunny visions are one thing, but when buying property in Spain, you simply can't avoid the paperwork – even though much is now digital. And honestly: I had more than just respect for the bureaucracy that was coming my way.
introduction.paragraph2: Spanish offices, foreign language, endless documents – that sounded like stress at first. But the fact is: Without this step, the dream of your own home in Spain remains just a dream.
introduction.tip: A small note: I didn't have some documents ready in time and had to catch up on a lot. So that this doesn't happen to you, I'll give you an overview of everything I really needed during my purchase process.

nie.title: The NIE Number – My Entry Ticket
nie.paragraph1: First things first: the NIE number (Número de Identificación de Extranjeros). Without it, nothing works – no bank account, no electricity contract, no purchase contract. It's basically your official fingerprint in Spain.
nie.paragraph2: The application is handled by the Policía Nacional. Appointments are available online, sometimes also spontaneously on site – with a lot of luck. Realistically, you have to expect waiting times of several weeks.
nie.paragraph3: Since I didn't have the opportunity to constantly lurk for free appointments in Spain, I commissioned a service provider: Spanieninfo (spanieninfo.biz). They handle the application for you if you sign a power of attorney at a German notary and make it valid for Spain with an apostille.
nie.tip: My tip: Take care of it in time, preferably before you find your dream apartment. Without NIE, you can't even take the first step in the purchase.

onSite.title: Application On-Site
onSite.step1: Book appointment online with Policía Nacional
onSite.step2: Go to the authority in person
onSite.step3: Pick up NIE after a few weeks

company.title: Application via Company
company.step1: Sign power of attorney at German notary
company.step3: Send documents by registered mail to Spain

bankAccount.title: A Spanish Bank Account – Nothing Works Without It
bankAccount.paragraph1: The next unavoidable step was the Spanish bank account. Whether mortgage, notary fees, property transfer tax or monthly utilities – nothing works without an account in Spain.
bankAccount.paragraph2: The choice is great: from Santander to CaixaBank to Bankinter, many banks offer special accounts for foreigners. What you need is relatively clear: your NIE, passport and – if you want to deposit equity immediately – proof of the origin of the money.
bankAccount.paragraph3: I myself opted for an account as a non-resident. It costs a bit more, but it's the simplest solution for everyone who doesn't live permanently in Spain.
bankAccount.tip: I opened my account quite late with the help of my gestoría – it worked just in time, but I would recommend doing it much earlier.

requirements.title: Required Documents
requirements.item1: NIE number (Número de Identificación de Extranjeros)
requirements.item3: Proof of money origin (for larger amounts)

financing.title: Financing Options – German vs. Spanish Banks
financing.paragraph1: The question of financing is a real sticking point. German banks wave off when it comes to Spanish real estate – unless you have collateral in Germany (e.g., your own property that you can encumber there).
financing.paragraph2: So the Spanish banks remain: Santander, Bankinter, CaixaBank and many others. However, the conditions are stricter for non-residents: usually maximum 70% financing, stricter credit checks and higher interest rates.
financing.paragraph3: In my case, my real estate agency offered me a partner who was supposed to accompany the entire financing process – but for a hefty 4,000 € fee. I declined and researched myself instead.
financing.tip: I can highly recommend Idealista/Hipotecas: there you get offers from various banks in comparison, can use the service in English and even communicate via WhatsApp – for free!

expectations.title: What to expect from Spanish banks
expectations.item1: Higher interest rates than German banks

gestoria.title: Gestoría or Lawyer – My Salvation in the Paper Chaos
gestoria.paragraph1: And here comes my personal secret tip: a gestoría. Of all the costs in the purchase process, those for my gestoría were the only ones where I didn't even flinch. In retrospect, it was the best decision after buying the apartment itself.
gestoria.paragraph2: The weeks between preliminary contract and notary appointment were by far the most stressful time of my life. You already have a lot of money in the project – and know that you can lose it if you miss a deadline or a document is missing.
gestoria.paragraph3: I ended up quite randomly at Gestoría Carrasco & Fischer in Orihuela Costa – and was looked after top from day one. They explained the Contrato de Arras to me, translated the contracts, took over communication with the bank and accompanied me to the notary.
gestoria.paragraph4: Alternatively (or additionally), you can also hire a lawyer for real estate law. They mainly check whether the property is legally clean: no open legal disputes, no illegal constructions, no nasty surprises. Costs more, but provides security. I myself refrained from doing so – also because I had already signed the Contrato de Arras in a rush.
gestoria.tip: Without a gestoría, I would probably have lost my mind during the purchase process. A gestoría is an office that guides you through all the bureaucracy in Spain – from taxes to contracts to re-registration of electricity and water. The investment in professional help was the best decision for me after buying the apartment itself.

additionalFormalities.title: Additional Formalities & Tips That Are Easy to Forget
additionalFormalities.intro: What I didn't know at first: there are still a few smaller things that you quickly overlook – but which are crucial.

nie.title: NIE vs. NIF
nie.description: The NIE is the identification number, the NIF becomes relevant as soon as you become tax active in Spain.

digitalCert.title: Digital Certificate
digitalCert.description: A kind of digital ID for online government services. Saves time and nerves – I still don't have it today, but it's on my list.

insurance.title: Insurance
insurance.description: Many banks insist on household or building insurance before they pay out the loan. So take care of it in time.

notary.title: Notary Choice
notary.description: As a buyer, you can choose the notary yourself. There are differences both in price and in language skills.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
conclusion.text: These are in my view the most important points that should be completed before it really gets down to business with contracts and notary appointments. Above all, having a good gestoría by your side early on can save you enormous stress.
